text: well we are taking you now to Malaysia
because the veteran politician Marty
Mohammed is meeting the King today
because he's discussing forming a new
government he is 92 years old and he led
the opposition parties which took
victory in the general election that
means the first transfer of power in
Malaysia since independence some 61
years ago well his opponent Najib Razak
has conceded defeat our Southeast Asia
correspondent Jonathan head is in Kuala
lumper for us first of all 92 that is
some age to take over leadership of your
country quite a comeback
it is an extraordinary comeback when you
think this man dominated not just
Malaysia with this region with his
towering personality in the 1980s and
90s he retired in 2003 he was already an
old man then I have to say watch him on
the campaign trail he's got the energy
of somebody half his age and his press
conference today after a pretty
sleepless night his wit was as sharp as
it ever has been there were questions
though about how this would proceed
remember as you say this has never
happened before Malaysians never had a
transfer of power constitutionally the
procedure is pretty obvious the
constitutional monarch that's one of
whoever of Malaysia's nine rotate Kings
takes the rotating position as a king of
the whole country is supposed simply to
swear him in and much the same way it
happens in Britain but there have been
delays dr. Mahajan got quite frustrated
earlier today because it hadn't happened
we now believe that appointment is for
about two and a half hours time and he's
already gone to the palace so we think
everything's in place now and it seems
to be just because of the unprecedented
nature of this power transfer that
things have gone rather slowly what
change is he likely to bring in into the
leadership of Malaysia and do you think
that he will stay for the entire course
well he won't stay for the entire course
because he's repeated again today the
promise that he made when he joined the
opposition that he would step aside
after two years within two years and
make way for his old nemesis and why
Ibrahim who is the opposition leader
who's now in jail now he was first
jailed by mahadji Muhammad himself back
in ninety at the 1990s when he was his
designated successor and fell out with
him and they've been bitter rivals but
they made up some say it's just a
coalition of convenience but he's
repeated time and again this is my
agreement I will take over merely to
smooth over the transition but within
two years I'll get a pardon for Anwar
Ibrahim and he will then be able because
you me gets elected as an MP to take
over so there is a plan there and dr.
Marty's plan is to step aside now the
opposition has quite a comprehensive
plan the GUP the outgoing governments
accuse them of being economically
reckless they are going to cancel a very
unpopular sales tax but of course that
will leave a hole in the government's
revenues but there are so many other
issues that Malaysians want to address
not just the cost of living but also of
course crucially investigations into
corruption by outgoing Prime Minister
Najib Razak and that is something that
dr mahadji has stressed today will
happen
johnathan head thanks very much indeed
